author: chron.com
title: The best places to celebrate National Tortilla Chip Day in Houston -

organizations.name: la mejor salsa de mi mama
houston chronicle image

text:
Photo: Alison Cook Image 1 of / 64 64 PHOTOS: The best places to celebrate National Tortilla Chip Day in Houston
The iconic Laurenzo family tortillas chips with red and green table salsas on display at the El Tiempo on Navigation. They didn't last long on the table.
Click through to see where to get your fix in Houston according to Houston Chronicle food experts Alison Cook, Syd Kearney, Greg Morago and Jody Schmal.... less PHOTOS: The best places to celebrate National Tortilla Chip Day in Houston
The iconic Laurenzo family tortillas chips with red and green table salsas on display at the El Tiempo on Navigation. They didn't last ... more Photo: Alison Cook Image 2 of 64 EL BIG BAD Address: 419 Travis, 713-229-8181; elbigbad.com Salsafication: El Big Bad goes El Big when it comes to salsa. Four imaginative, chef-driven salsas grace the menu. Each brings something unique to the table. There's a satisfying charred tomato salsa shot through with onion, serrano chile, garlic, lime and cilantro; a vibrant salsa verde (tomatillo and serrano) with just the right amount of fresh green flash; Jalisco Vinegar (a tangy wallop of tart heat laced with subtle flavors of toasted seeds, baking spices and chile de arbol potency); and Cranberry Picosa (fruit forward sweetness slammed by a habanero scorching). Multiple salsas? Four -- count 'em -- four. Free: $3 for one; $8 for three; $10 for all four. Chips: Made in-house; they're warm, satisfying corny comfort. Grade: Excellent. Other: A favorite place to drink downtown. But don't confuse the gastro-cantina with a margarita mill; El Big Bad has some wonderfully rich, satisfying, true-flavors cooking going on. less EL BIG BAD Address: 419 Travis, 713-229-8181; elbigbad.com Salsafication: El Big Bad goes El Big when it comes to salsa. Four imaginative, chef-driven salsas grace the menu. Each brings something unique to the ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 3 of 64 CHAPULTEPEC LUPITA Address: 813 Richmond, 713-522-2365 Salsafication: This no-frills, combo plate joint offers some darn tasty salsa. It's the kind of personal, familial elixir your favorite tia might have made -- a brilliant kitchen salsa with vivid, satisfying flavors. Plenty of chile sting, tomato and fresh cilantro brightness, and a slightly rough, scoopable texture that have you consuming a bowl even before your second beer arrives. Multiple salsas? Just the red. Free: Yes. Chips: Fine chips but they could have served us cardboard; we'd use whatever vehicle to attack this hot, homespun charmer. Grade: Excellent. Other: Chapultepec is open 24 hours so you can get at this wonderful salsa whenever the craving hits you. less CHAPULTEPEC LUPITA Address: 813 Richmond, 713-522-2365 Salsafication: This no-frills, combo plate joint offers some darn tasty salsa. It's the kind of personal, familial elixir your favorite tia might have made ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 4 of 64 EL TIEMPO CANTINA Address: Multiple locaitons; eltiiempocantina.com Salsafication: The fact that this brand comes from Mama Ninfa's talented clan is assurance enough that you're getting authentic Houston salsa at the many El Tiempo outposts. The green seems more emulsified than the original Ninfa's on Navigation but no less crave-inducing. The red, though, is a thing of beauty -- a vivid, tomato-forward sauce that is visibly potent and full of flavor. It's not terribly chile hot but it is as well rounded a red as you can get. Multiple salsas? Both green and red served automatically. Free: Yes. Chips: Abundant crunch replaced automatically and often. Grade: Extraordinary. Other: It's hard to believe that the restaurant's insanely enormous menu is delivered in such top-notch fashion. But it is and that's why El Tiempo, for many, is the ultimate go-to Tex-Mex. less EL TIEMPO CANTINA Address: Multiple locaitons; eltiiempocantina.com Salsafication: The fact that this brand comes from Mama Ninfa's talented clan is assurance enough that you're getting authentic Houston salsa ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 5 of 64 SYLVIA'S ENCHILDA KITCHEN Address: Three Houston locations; sylviasenchiladas.com Salsafication: The red salsa is served so hot the bowl was steaming at the table. There must be a cauldron in the kitchen gurgling with this humble brew that sports visible feathers of tomato skin and roasted flecks. This is a loving, mama-style salsa that isn't chile hot but pleases with its homey, flavorful goodness. Multiple salsas?: Not advertised but there's a habanero version of this table salsa; ask for it if you need the heat. Free: Yes. Chips: Hot, thin yumminess. Grade: Very good. Other: Owner Sylvia Casares (known as Houston's Queen of Tex-Mex Cuisine and/or Houston's Enchilada Queen) is a born educator. Her cooking school classes help preserve Tex-Mex culinary traditions. less SYLVIA'S ENCHILDA KITCHEN Address: Three Houston locations; sylviasenchiladas.com Salsafication: The red salsa is served so hot the bowl was steaming at the table. There must be a cauldron in the kitchen gurgling ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 6 of 64 BERRYHILL BAJA GRILL Address: Eight Houston-area locations; berryhillbajagrill.com Salsafication: A self-serve salsa bar is one of the signature features of this Houston-born chain. That offers an option not available at table-service restaurants. Using the ladle you can decide on how saucy or chunky you want your salsa. The large diced veg in this tomato-forward salsa tastes super fresh and complements an order of Berryhill's famous tamales. But those looking for heat will be disappointed. Multiple salsas?: No, but there is a ranch dressing/sauce on the salsa bar, as well as several hot sauces and a chunky pickled carrots and onion. Free: Yes. Chips: Thick cut and probably tasty if they didn't spend so much time of their time under a heat lamp. Grade: Good. Other: The salsa may lack heat but not so the Killer B cookies, one of the chain's dessert options. The chili-flecked cookies -- a take on a pecan sandie -- are delicious and deceptively spicy. less BERRYHILL BAJA GRILL Address: Eight Houston-area locations; berryhillbajagrill.com Salsafication: A self-serve salsa bar is one of the signature features of this Houston-born chain. That offers an option not ... more Photo: Syd Kearney / Chronicle Image 7 of 64 CUCHARA Address: 214 Fairview, 713-942-0000; cuchararestaurant.com Salsafication: A grand, verging on baroque salsa presentation of ridiculously delicious salsa flavors you won’t find anywhere else in Houston. The salsa trio here features Salsa Tia Martha (a green tomatillo version sporting an unexpected undertow of crushed peanut); Salsa de 5 Chiles (toasted chile heat enriched with porky chicharrones); and Salsa Quemada (a bold, fragrant stunner boasting “burnt” arbol chile skin). Multiple salsas? Three, and they’re all fabulous. Free: No, $9. Chips: They call them tortilla “fritters”; we call them chips. Grade: Extraordinary. Other: Last year Cuchara has an in-house salsa competition among six mothers who cook at the restaurant called La Mejor Salsa de Mi Mama. They were all salsas the cooks had learned from their mothers and grandmothers. It was magisterial stuff. The salsa program alone is reason enough to love Cuchara. less CUCHARA Address: 214 Fairview, 713-942-0000; cuchararestaurant.com Salsafication: A grand, verging on baroque salsa presentation of ridiculously delicious salsa flavors you won’t find anywhere else in Houston. ... more Photo: Staff Photo Image 8 of 64 SPANISH FLOWERS MEXICAN RESTAURANT Address: 4701 N. Main, 713-869-1706; spanishflowersrestaurant.com Salsafication: Spanish Flowers is a Houston institution but its salsa is bewilderingly weak. Chunky, yes, but bland and watery. There is practically no chile flavor in this soupy, almost tinny tomato brew that does little to please salsa fans. Multiple salsas? Only red was served to us. Free: Yes. Chips: Flavorless. Grade: Just OK. Other: Open 24 hours. According to website the restaurant takes a break on Tuesday nights when it closes at 10 p.m. (reopening Wednesday at 9 a.m.). less SPANISH FLOWERS MEXICAN RESTAURANT Address: 4701 N. Main, 713-869-1706; spanishflowersrestaurant.com Salsafication: Spanish Flowers is a Houston institution but its salsa is bewilderingly weak. Chunky, yes, but ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 9 of 64 TEOTIHUACAN MEXICAN CAFE Address: Three locations in Houston; teomexicancafe.com Salsafication: The red is a warm, flavorful mash with specs of roasted tomato. It separates a bit if left alone but there's no threat of that because it sports a nice chile kick; you want to keep eating. The green is better -- a deceptive pale-colored sauce that offers clean flavors of lime, cilantro and green chile brightness. Multiple salsas? Yes, both red and green are distinguished salsas. Free: Yes. Chips: Light, warm and crispy but we added some salt. Grade: Very good. Other: The restaurant has a great atmosphere where family gatherings and obvious regulars are happy to call home. The nachos are great and the guacamole fantastic. less TEOTIHUACAN MEXICAN CAFE Address: Three locations in Houston; teomexicancafe.com Salsafication: The red is a warm, flavorful mash with specs of roasted tomato. It separates a bit if left alone but there's no ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 10 of 64 THE PASTRY WAR Address: 310 Main, 713-225-3310; thepastrywar.com Salsafication: Swamp creature. The boggy chile stew served at this serious downtown mezcal bar takes no prisoners. It is unapologetically combustible with ferocious chile heat. A red, tomato-based salsa, it almost tips to green in color for all its nearly flammable chile glory. We've asked what's in it, they won't tell. But whoever is making this fierce, verdant sludge is a salsa master. Multiple salsas? Nope, but this one practically straddles two worlds. Free: $5.99 for chips and salsa. Chips: Get rid of them. The awful, red/white/blue supermarket tortilla chips are unworthy of such glorious salsa. Deserves so much better. Grade: Extraordinary. Other: The chicken and pork tamales served here are dreamy. We also like the queso. And that's it for food at this bar that boasts what is surely the state's most intelligent agave spirits program. less THE PASTRY WAR Address: 310 Main, 713-225-3310; thepastrywar.com Salsafication: Swamp creature. The boggy chile stew served at this serious downtown mezcal bar takes no prisoners. It is unapologetically ... more Photo: Julie Soefer Image 11 of 64 CHUY'S Address: Eight Houston-area restaurants; chuys.com Salsafication: The chunky concoction that Austin-born Chuy's delivers with its chips is related more to pico de gallo than salsa. The color may be anemic but those peppers sure aren't. The burn just builds, in a good way. Multiple salsas? Not a salsa, but there is second condiment that often comes to the table automatically. The jalapeño ranch dip is addictive and soothes any residual burn from the salsa. If it doesn't appear, just ask. Free: Yes. Chips: So light and thin that they often make the chunky salsa a challenge to eat. Grade: Good. Other: The complimentary fully loaded nacho bar at happy hour is one of the best deals in town. less CHUY'S Address: Eight Houston-area restaurants; chuys.com Salsafication: The chunky concoction that Austin-born Chuy's delivers with its chips is related more to pico de gallo than salsa. The color may be ... more Image 12 of 64 CHILOSO'S TACO HOUSE Address: 701 E. 20th, 713-868-2273; chilosostacohouse.com Salsafication: The red is a wow: an honest, homey sauce sporting intense chile flavor. A loose brew, its components are obvious: discernible, real tomato, onion and chile seeds. We had to ask for squeeze bottles of the green and one taste assured us that this is fiery fuel of the salsa gods. It's incendiary, intense stuff that will blow you away if you're not using it sparingly. But for those who crave the zenith of salsa heat, this green is chile heat heaven. Multiple salsas? Yes. Delicious red and powerful green. Free: No, $2 for basket of chips and salsa. Chips: Warm, and house made. Slightly greasy but we appreciated the fresh, hot chips effort. Grade: Excellent. Other: A popular spot for obvious reasons: fresh flour tortilla tacos, abundant portions, fresh ingredients and Mexican realness in the kitchen. less CHILOSO'S TACO HOUSE Address: 701 E. 20th, 713-868-2273; chilosostacohouse.com Salsafication: The red is a wow: an honest, homey sauce sporting intense chile flavor. A loose brew, its components are obvious: ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 13 of 64 LA TAPATIA Address: Multiple locations in Houston; latapatiahouston.com Salsafication: Within seconds of sitting down you are met with a big, welcoming bowl of chips and both red and green salsa. The red sits nicely on chips and sports an almost perfect body and texture. It's textbook red that effortlessly balances the tomato/chile equation. The tomatillo green also nails the texture department; flavor-wise it's got it all going on: tang, just the right amount of heat and easy likability. Multiple salsas? Everyday salsa, red and green, should be this good. Free: Yes. Chips: Good, standard crunchers. Grade: Very good. Other: Unfussy go-to Tex-Mex doesn't aim to outperform in the standard repertoire. And that's probably part of La Tapatia's easygoing charm. less LA TAPATIA Address: Multiple locations in Houston; latapatiahouston.com Salsafication: Within seconds of sitting down you are met with a big, welcoming bowl of chips and both red and green salsa. The red sits ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 14 of 64 GOODE CO. TAQUERIA Address: 4902 Kirby, 713-520-9153; goodecompany.com Salsafication: We might wish for more capsaicin sting from this loose-textured red salsa but it's the kind of sauce you want to pour every everything -- your taco and fajita dinners, midges and all the other huevo-based day-starter options. With its discernible roasted its and mild tomato goodness, this is a serviceable salsa that can please all palates. Want more chile kick? Load up on the free pickled jalapeños. Multiple salsas? Red's the word here. Free: Yes. Chips: Nice, friendly chips. Grade: Very good. Other: The Goode quality stamp is at play here as it is throughout the Goode family brands. You might be paying a bit more for your Tex-Mex than at other joints, but you're getting great food and service. less GOODE CO. TAQUERIA Address: 4902 Kirby, 713-520-9153; goodecompany.com Salsafication: We might wish for more capsaicin sting from this loose-textured red salsa but it's the kind of sauce you want to pour every ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 15 of 64 HUGO’S Address: 1600 Westheimer; hugosrestaurant.net Salsafication: The sole table salsa, meant to accompany the house-fried totopos, is a salsa Mexicana so lively and fresh tasting and soft that it fools you into thinking it will be mild before socking you with its green-chile heat. Chef Hugo Ortega uses the chile pods with seeds and veins intact for more capsaicin oomph. A pulpy room-temperature mince, it’s flecked with green chile and cilantro bits, deepened by onion and the garlic that is one of Ortega’s favorite salsa touches. Those spindles of tomato skin bristling here and there? Proof that fresh tomatoes have been roasted to make the salsa, which intensifies the flavors. Multiple salsas? Yes, many and varied, made to go with specific dishes. One of Ortega’s newest potions is the salsa macha, an evil-looking blackish sludge gritty with solids: garlic shards, sesame seeds, cilantro seeds, dried red chiles. This specialty of Veracruz hits with a toastiness followed by a note of sweetness and then bam! Sudden, throat-catching heat that hurts so good. The avocado-tomatillo green salsa is killer stuff, beautifully coarse and bright with hunks of tart tomatillo and a controlled flare of green chile heat that lingers on the tongue. The avocado component subtly mellows the effect. Free: No. Order the salsa Mexicana for $7 with totopos and guacamole. Salsa macha comes with roasted cauliflower salad; avocado-tomatillo salsa comes with Tacos Dorados, soft little folds of puffy fried potato. Chips: Sturdy house-fried totopos that emit a sharp crack with each bite. Grade: Extraordinary (Mexicana, macha and avocado-tomatillo). less HUGO’S Address: 1600 Westheimer; hugosrestaurant.net Salsafication: The sole table salsa, meant to accompany the house-fried totopos, is a salsa Mexicana so lively and fresh tasting and soft that it fools you ... more Image 16 of 64 LAST CONCERT CAFE Address: 1402 Nance, 713-226-8563; lastconcert.com Salsafication: It might not be the first place that comes to mind when you're craving Tex-Mex (and that's your own fault) because you'll have a rewarding experience when you want to get on with a chips and salsa throwdown. The salsa here is good-natured: bright red tomato flavor churned with abundant cilantro and serrano pepper. It's made daily and you can tell from its direct, clean, fresh impact. It's the kind of salsa you wish you could make at home and would taste just as good. Multiple salsas? No. Free: Yes. Chips: Good, workman-like chips. Grade: Very good. Other: You'll have to knock at the red door to gain entrance but Last Concert is as unpretentious and welcoming as they come. In a city that has a high tolerance for artifice, this hippie, be-yourself cafe puts on zero airs, making it a true come-as-you-are social hall for dependable Tex-Mex and uncontrived atmosphere. less LAST CONCERT CAFE Address: 1402 Nance, 713-226-8563; lastconcert.com Salsafication: It might not be the first place that comes to mind when you're craving Tex-Mex (and that's your own fault) because you'll ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 17 of 64 CYCLONE ANAYA'S Address: Multiple Houston locations; cycloneanaya.com Salsafication: Tomato bomb. And we mean that in a good way. The salsa here is so tomato forward it almost feels like an Italian marinara. It's got great body and mild heat but it's darn tasty, addictive even. Multiple salsas? If they have a green, we don't know about it. Free: Yes. Chips: Nice, crispy, plentiful. Grade: Very good. Other: We love the wrestler story at the heart of Cyclone Anaya (and the Midtown store is one of our favorite places to spend a chips and salsa afternoon). less CYCLONE ANAYA'S Address: Multiple Houston locations; cycloneanaya.com Salsafication: Tomato bomb. And we mean that in a good way. The salsa here is so tomato forward it almost feels like an Italian marinara. ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 18 of 64 LUPE TORTILLA MEXICAN RESTAURANT Address: Multiple locations; lupetortilla.com Salsafication: Not really a traditional table salsa at all, Lupe's chip dipper is really more a pico de gallo; a chunky salsa fresca with a predominant tomato flavor and not much else. It doesn't carry a lot of heat; it's watery too, which may be a let down to those who like to drown their tacos with a traditional blended salsa. Multiple salsas? Instead of offering a second salsa, Lupe serves a bowl of charro beans. Warm, satisfying, and a nice, unexpected touch. If you want extra heat with your food, ask for a mess of their delicious pickled jalapeños. Free: Yes. Chips: Light as air and addictive. They'll bring you as much as you can crunch down. Grade: Just OK. Other: Lupe's fajitas, which sport a special taste, have earned legions of fans. less LUPE TORTILLA MEXICAN RESTAURANT Address: Multiple locations; lupetortilla.com Salsafication: Not really a traditional table salsa at all, Lupe's chip dipper is really more a pico de gallo; a chunky salsa ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 19 of 64 HABANERA & THE GRINGO Address: 9902 Interstate 45; habagringo.com Salsification: Brightened with both lemon and lime and rounded with garlic, the red table salsa resembles a marvelous, slightly soupy pico de gallo. Meticulously chopped tomato, onion and jalapeño impart a fine fresh texture, and cilantro adds an herbal twinge. Multiple salsas? No. Free: Yes. Chips: Sturdy and house-fried, they snap, crackle and pop. Grade: Extraordinary. Other: The food at this southeast Houston newcomer near Hobby Airport is personal and frisky; the salsa’s just the beginning. Don’t miss the frozen margaritas with hand-muddled tropical fruits and seasonings mixed in. less HABANERA & THE GRINGO Address: 9902 Interstate 45; habagringo.com Salsification: Brightened with both lemon and lime and rounded with garlic, the red table salsa resembles a marvelous, slightly soupy pico de ... more Image 20 of 64 SPANISH VILLAGE Address: 4720 Almeda; spanishvillagerestaurant.com Salsafication: The fierce red table salsa here has hardly changed a lot over the 50 years we’ve been scarfing it down with chips and more chips. It’s thin and soupy, shot through with onion and a sudden wall of jalapeño heat strong enough to clear sinuses. It’s not about depth or nuance; it’s about feeling the elemental burn. Food photographer Penny de los Santos says it’s a dead ringer for the salsa she grew up with in the Rio Grande Valley. Multiple salsas? No. Free: Yes. Chips: Thin, crackly, salty. Grade: Good. Other: This quirky Tex-Mex mainstay dishes out classic cheese-and-onion enchiladas, cult fried chicken (!) and amazing margaritas bristling with slivers of frozen lime juice. less SPANISH VILLAGE Address: 4720 Almeda; spanishvillagerestaurant.com Salsafication: The fierce red table salsa here has hardly changed a lot over the 50 years we’ve been scarfing it down with chips and more ... more Image 21 of 64 TACO PALENQUE Address: 3000 Woodridge; tacopalenquehouston.com Salsafication: The standout on the serve-yourself salsa bar is the deep-red Salsa Picosa, which hits the palate with a profound sun-baked roastiness and spreading heat. Flecks of charred chile and plenty of seeds keep the slightly puréed texture real. Salty, tart and dusky, it’s hard to stop eating. Mutiple salsas? Yes, three. The good basic tomatillo green salsa hits with a quick flare of green-chile heat; and the dark, blackened Salsa Tatemada strikes with a major delayed sear that can make your nose run. Free: Yes. Chips: Thinny-thin and brittle. Grade: Excellent (Picosa); good (tomatillo and Tatemada). Other: The meats from the Rio Grande Valley-based chain are merely serviceable, but the earthy bean-and-cheese tacos wrapped in flour tortillas are primal, the salsa bar’s fun, and the agua fresca jamaica is wonderful in its refusal to cloy. less TACO PALENQUE Address: 3000 Woodridge; tacopalenquehouston.com Salsafication: The standout on the serve-yourself salsa bar is the deep-red Salsa Picosa, which hits the palate with a profound sun-baked ... more Image 22 of 64 EL PATIO MEXICAN RESTAURANT Address: 6444 Westheimer, 713-780-0410; elpatio.com Salsafication: The salsa set before us looks on the thin side, innocuous even. But that bowl of red has some welcome heat and packs a lot of flavor. Served cold, it's a great condiment for El Patio's classic Tex-Mex menu. Multiple salsas? No. Free: Yes. Chips: Incredibly thin and crispy. Light vehicles for the house's spicy tonic. Grade: Very good. Other: Club No Minors memories are plentiful (or are they?). Blame the infamous blue margaritas everyone swears have to be the most potent in town. Great happy hour prices make El Patio a perfect day to smash the afternoon into a million golden pieces. less EL PATIO MEXICAN RESTAURANT Address: 6444 Westheimer, 713-780-0410; elpatio.com Salsafication: The salsa set before us looks on the thin side, innocuous even. But that bowl of red has some welcome heat and packs ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 23 of 64 LOS CUCOS MEXICAN CAFE Address: 17 Houston-area restaurants; loscucos.com Salsafication: The red salsa at this Houston-born chain is served warm in a cup with a pouring lip. With its roasted bits of red chilies and tomato, it is as pretty to look at as it is good to eat. Pleasant vinegar finish. Multiple salsas? Yes, the pale green cream sauce is perked up with fresh cilantro. Free: Yes. Chips: They eat lighter than they look and that's a good thing. Grade: Very good. Other: For a decadent lunch or afternoon snack, try the seafood nachos. A small order is plenty as this is one rich dish, topped with crab, shrimp, Monterey Jack, sour cream and guacamole. And it goes down swell with a pucker-inducing margarita. less LOS CUCOS MEXICAN CAFE Address: 17 Houston-area restaurants; loscucos.com Salsafication: The red salsa at this Houston-born chain is served warm in a cup with a pouring lip. With its roasted bits of red chilies ... more Image 24 of 64 100% TAQUITO Address: 3245 Southwest Fwy., 713-665-3310; 100taquito.com Salsafication: Served piping hot, the tomato salsa is hearty with a well-rounded flavor. With each dip you want more. Multiple salsas? Yes, there's a second salsa -- a bright, vivid green charmer that's tangy and heat-forward. There's also a third, too: a straightforward, unexciting pico. Free: No; $2.29 for an order of chips and salsa. Chips: Unsalted chips kept warm until you order. Grade: Good. Other: We love the refried black beans here as well as the use of fresco cheese on the addictive tostadas, sopes and banderitas (crisp beef or chicken flautas sauced to resemble the flag of Mexico). less 100% TAQUITO Address: 3245 Southwest Fwy., 713-665-3310; 100taquito.com Salsafication: Served piping hot, the tomato salsa is hearty with a well-rounded flavor. With each dip you want more. Multiple salsas? Yes, ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 25 of 64 PAPPASITO'S Address: More than a dozen Houston-area restaurants; pappasitos.com Salsafication: Served warm, this light but spicy salsa is reason alone to visit this Houston-based, family owned chain. The roasted vegetables and peppers always taste super fresh. If we had any complaint, it is the that the salsa vessels just get smaller and smaller. Multiple salsas? No, but the creamy avocado dip is a pleasant if unremarkable accessory. Free: Yes. Chips: See-through thin chips are served warm and satisfyingly salty. Grade: Very good. Other: Here's the way to do Pappasito's. Show up at 3 o'clock and order the addictive, butter-drenched Chipotle Shrimp that are only available at lunch, which is served until 4. The genius is that you've timed it just right for happy hour pricing on your margarita. less PAPPASITO'S Address: More than a dozen Houston-area restaurants; pappasitos.com Salsafication: Served warm, this light but spicy salsa is reason alone to visit this Houston-based, family owned chain. The roasted ... more Image 26 of 64 EIGHT ROW FLINT Address: 1039 Yale, 832-767-4002; eightrowflint.com Salsafication: Chunky, vegetal and well-balanced, this fresh salsa does this contemporary Heights icehouse proud. Mix some into the pure avocado-mash guacamole and you have yourself a treat you might find hard to share. Multiple salsas? No, just the one. Free: No, $5 for chips and salsa. Chips: The star of the show, these hot fresh chips are fashioned from house-made tortillas prepared with heirloom corn. Thick and substantial, they deliver excellent corn flavor. Grade: Very good. Other: This new, always-packed icehouse is from the partners of Revival Market and Coltivare, Morgan Weber and chef Ryan Pera. There's an almost overwhelming bourbon menu here that might take you a year to get through. But isn't that the point? less EIGHT ROW FLINT Address: 1039 Yale, 832-767-4002; eightrowflint.com Salsafication: Chunky, vegetal and well-balanced, this fresh salsa does this contemporary Heights icehouse proud. Mix some into the pure ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 27 of 64 ULA'S MEXICAN RESTAURANT & CANTINA Address: 5555 Washington, 832-491-0510; 9009 Sienna Christus, Missouri City, 281-778-9345; texmexicanfood.com Salsafication: Served warm, this brick-colored salsa suffers from a lack of heat and depth. Thanks to a heavy hand with the onion, it recalls a slightly sweet marinara. Multiples salsas? No, but the chips do come with a bowl of thickened, bacon-flecked charro beans. Free: Yes. Chips: Medium thick, which is a requirement if you're using them as a vessel for the bean "dip." Grade: Just OK. Other: Try the Mexican smoked ribs, which are char-grilled and basted with chef/owner Ulises Gonzalez's spicy barbecue sauce. less ULA'S MEXICAN RESTAURANT & CANTINA Address: 5555 Washington, 832-491-0510; 9009 Sienna Christus, Missouri City, 281-778-9345; texmexicanfood.com Salsafication: Served warm, this brick-colored salsa suffers from ... more Image 28 of 64 EL PUEBLITO PATIO Adddress: 1423 Richmond; elpueblitopatio.com Salsafication: That pale green potion on your table looks like a regular old salsa verde. But surprise: The base is roughly puréed pineapple, and the salsa comes on all innocent sweetness, followed by sneaky green chile heat, an edge of cilantro and a savory note of onion. It seems odd and insipid at first blush, until the heat kicks in. Then, despite your better judgment, you’re hooked. Multiple salsas? Yes. Pueblito made its name originally with that pineapple salsa, which caused a stir when the restaurant opened as El Pueblito Place in 1997. But the red table salsa is even better. A cool, rough tomato purée that creeps up on you with a big front-of-the palate sear that migrates to the back of the throat as the heat subsides, it has a nice balance of salt, tartness, cilantro and onion flavors. Free: Yes. Chips: Deep-gold, medium-thick, slightly bubbled surface. They’re decent-quality commercial specimens but nothing special. Grade: Good (pineapple); very good (red salsa). Other: Despite the outrageous charms of the big Las Vegas pool-club-style patio — complete with draped semi-private dining pavilions, huge palms and a waterfall — the vaguely coastal Mexican food here is so-so at best. You’re safest scarfing the salsas while sipping one of the surprisingly good, tart frozen margaritas at the bar. less EL PUEBLITO PATIO Adddress: 1423 Richmond; elpueblitopatio.com Salsafication: That pale green potion on your table looks like a regular old salsa verde. But surprise: The base is roughly puréed pineapple, and ... more Image 29 of 64 GUADALAJARA HACIENDA Address: Four locations; guadalajarahacienda.com Salsafication: Served icy cold, the tomato-forward red salsa has a pleasant pulpy texture and vinegary bite. Multiple salsas? Yes. Alongside their red salsa, Guadalajara serves a mostly forgettable creamy cilantro sauce. Free: Yes. Chips: See-through thin and well-salted. Grade: Good. Other: This locally owned chain recently renovated its Southwest Freeway location and gave it a spiffy new name, Guad Texas Chef-Mex. less GUADALAJARA HACIENDA Address: Four locations; guadalajarahacienda.com Salsafication: Served icy cold, the tomato-forward red salsa has a pleasant pulpy texture and vinegary bite. Multiple salsas? Yes. Alongside ... more Image 30 of 64 ARMANDOS Address: 2630 Westheimer, 713-520-1738; armandosrestaurant.com Salsafication: The red salsa is a soupy concoction; almost like a stewed tomato sauce. It's got body but not a lot of flavor depth. But Armandos regulars crave it; let's call it a sentimental salsa (if you grew up with it, it's what you want). Multiple salsas? Yes, the house tomatillo is a winner -- verdant, fragrant, delicious. Free: Yes. Chips: Nice chips served in a cone; we always end up wanting more. Grade: Good (red); very good (green). Other: Even when it's going full tilt (especially on Thursday nights when it brings out River Oaks' dancing fools), Armandos servers manage to take good care. There's always another cocktail heading your way almost before you ask for it. Love the cheese enchiladas. less ARMANDOS Address: 2630 Westheimer, 713-520-1738; armandosrestaurant.com Salsafication: The red salsa is a soupy concoction; almost like a stewed tomato sauce. It's got body but not a lot of flavor depth. But ... more Photo: Greg Morago Image 31 of 64 ARNALDO RICHARDS' PICOS Address: 3601 Kirby; picos.net Salsafication: There’s red table salsa and green, in the binary tradition Ninfa’s made famous, but the green salsa is all tart tomatillo zip instead of avocado creaminess, which makes it wonderfully bright and memorable. There’s just enough grippy green-chile heat to expand the tart-fruit, onion and cilantro flavors and keep them going. Mutiple salsas? Yes. The red salsa has enough roastiness of tomato, onion and chiles to give it depth and complexity. Free: Yes. Chips: Well-made skinny totopos. Grade: Extraordinary (green); excellent (red). Other: The shaker margaritas, served straight up, have set the premium standards for this iconic Houston cocktail for three decades now. Order one with any of the well-made regional Mexican dishes. less ARNALDO RICHARDS' PICOS Address: 3601 Kirby; picos.net Salsafication: There’s red table salsa and green, in the binary tradition Ninfa’s made famous, but the green salsa is all tart tomatillo zip instead of ... more Image 32 of 64 UNCLE JULIO'S Address: 20526 I-10, Katy; 832-464-8930; unclejulios.com Salsafication: Roasted onions, jalapeños and tomatoes give this salsa a pleasantly smokey flavor; the little bits of cilantro provide a fresh touch. Served warm, the thin salsa is perfect match for Uncle Julio's ethereal chips. Multiple salsas? No. Free: Yes. Chips: Deftly salted and whisper thin. Grade: Very good. Other: Make it a celebration with this Dallas-based chain's Chocolate Pinata. Diners use a small hammer to crack the egg-shaped chocolate and out pours mini churros and fresh fruit. less UNCLE JULIO'S Address: 20526 I-10, Katy; 832-464-8930; unclejulios.com Salsafication: Roasted onions, jalapeños and tomatoes give this salsa a pleasantly smokey flavor; the little bits of cilantro provide a ... more Image 33 of 64 CAFE ADOBE Address: 7620 I-10 at MarqE Center, 713-688-1700; 2329 Texas 6, Sugar Land, 281-277-1700; cafeadobe.com Salsafication: What has happened to our favorite party palace Cafe Adobe? The red salsa recently presented looked familiar, but had zero flavor. Multiple salsas? Yes, a verde version that is pleasantly tart but otherwise unremarkable. Free: Yes. Chips: Medium thickness. On our most recent visit, the chips could have been fresher. Grade: Just OK (red and green). Other: The "Perfect" Margarita -- a best frozen blend of Sauza Conmemorativo, Cointreau, Grand Marnier, Triple Sec, orange juice and freshly squeezed lime juice -- remains perfect and potent. less CAFE ADOBE Address: 7620 I-10 at MarqE Center, 713-688-1700; 2329 Texas 6, Sugar Land, 281-277-1700; cafeadobe.com Salsafication: What has happened to our favorite party palace Cafe Adobe? Wimpy and watery. Multiple salsas? No. Free: Yes. Chips: Pedestrian and crying out for salt. Grade: Just OK. Other: The newest location is lakeside at Hughes Landing in the Woodlands. It really is lovely on a sunny Sunday afternoon when the lake is dotted with paddlers and your only big decision is mimosa or margarita. less ESCALANTE'S Address: Six Houston-area restaurants; escalantes.net Salsafication: How does such a high-end Tex Mex chain get by with such a lowly salsa. It is super tart and vinegary and you're likely to get tripped up by some of those finely chopped fresh jalapeños. Multiple salsas? Yes. Molina's other red sauce is a less brash, toastier concoction with roasted jalapeño, arbol and pasilla peppers. It grows on you. Both red salsas are served automatically. If you'd prefer a salsa verde, request the Michael sauce that accompanies the popular chicken enchiladas. Free: Yes. Chips: Fresh and fragile (in a good way). Grade: Excellent (both reds and green). Other: One of Molina's best " para acompanar " is its mango pico de gallo. The warm salad accompanies a terrific sauteed camarones dish known as Raulito's Shrimp Special. less MOLINA'S CANTINA Address: 7901 Westheimer, 713-782-0861; 4720 Washington, 713-862-0013; 3801 Bellaire, 713-432-1626; molinascantina.com Salsafication: The "original" salsa -- the recipe is more than 70 ... more Image 36 of 64 TACOS A GO GO Address: 3704 Main and 2941 White Oak; tacosagogo.com Salsafication: The colorful, locally-owned fast-casual joint offers four varieties at its serve-yourself salsa bar. All are meant to complement the menu’s taco variety; just ladle your choice(s) into tiny plastic ramekins to pour and dip as you please. Our go-to? The green Diablo, the hottest of the bunch, is all juicy-fresh with raw serrano peppers tempered slightly by a bit of tomatillo, lime juice, cilantro and onion. Multiple salsas? Yes, four. The sweet/medium-spicy traditional Roja blends roasted tomatoes with plentiful garlic, cilantro, chopped onion and chile de arbol specks. The smooth, mostly-mild Verde stars roasted tomatillos with a kick of serrano, while the deep, rust-red Fuego sauce is all smoke with dry-roasted chipotle chiles. Free: Yes. Chips: Medium-thick housemade chips come with orders of guacamole ($4.59), queso ($3.99) and salsa Roja ($2.99, a larger portion). Grade: Excellent (Diablo), very good (Roja, Verde), good (Fuego). Other: The oft-overlooked nachos here — a heaping pile of queso-laden chips topped with black or refried beans, crisp shreds of lettuce, tomatoes, pickled jalapenos and any taco meat — are arguably among the city’s best. less TACOS A GO GO Address: 3704 Main and 2941 White Oak; tacosagogo.com Salsafication: The colorful, locally-owned fast-casual joint offers four varieties at its serve-yourself salsa bar. All are meant to ... more Image 37 of 64 LOPEZ MEXICAN RESTAURANT Address: 11606 Wilcrest, 281-495-2436; vivalopez.com Salsafication: A mild tasting salsa fresca that has been served by this southwest Houston since 1978. More of a seasoning for topping tacos and nachos than a stand-alone salsa. Multiple salsas? No. Free: Yes. Chips: Medium thick and pleasantly golden. Grade: Just OK. Other: The signature drink is the Dos Pinas. A summery drink built on pineapple-infused tequila. less LOPEZ MEXICAN RESTAURANT Address: 11606 Wilcrest, 281-495-2436; vivalopez.com Salsafication: A mild tasting salsa fresca that has been served by this southwest Houston since 1978. More of a seasoning for topping ... more Image 38 of 64 NINFA'S ON NAVIGATION Address: 2704 Navigation, 713-228-1175; ninfas.com Salsafication: The city’s original benchmark green salsa is still a thing of wonder: Delectable, creamy, essential. It’s the verdant ointment of our lives — good for what ails you, a culinary salve we crave day in and day out. The red, with is classic roasted tomato flavor and its easy likability, is good too, but it’s the green we turn to as the ultimate comfort sauce. Multiple salsas? Yes. Red and green, both famous. The pickled vegetables with their tangy heat are a nice touch. Ask for them. Your server also will give you as much jalapeño fire as you need. Free: Yes. Chips: Good crunchers. Grade: Extraordinary. Other: Mama Ninfa pioneered the two salsa service and it remains one of her most remarkable, enduring legacies. less NINFA'S ON NAVIGATION Address: 2704 Navigation, 713-228-1175; ninfas.com Salsafication: The city’s original benchmark green salsa is still a thing of wonder: Delectable, creamy, essential. It’s the verdant ... more Photo: Courtesy Photo Image 39 of 64 DONERAKI Address: 300 Gulfgate Mall; doneraki.com Salsafication: The red sauce here is so good it’s an attraction in and of itself. Served warm, the salsa roja has a runny, pureed texture amplified by dried red chile seeds, dark flecks of toasted chile skin and spindles of roasted tomato skin. It sings with roastiness and plenty of chile heat that blooms on the lips and the tongue. One bowlful is never enough. Multiple salsas? No. Free: Yes. Chips: Thin, delicate, lots of crunch. Grade: Excellent. Other: The salsa roja is particularly good on the Fajitadillas, one of Doneraki’s better dishes. less DONERAKI Address: 300 Gulfgate Mall; doneraki.com Salsafication: The red sauce here is so good it’s an attraction in and of itself. Chenevert; irmasoriginal.com Salsafication: The only trouble with Irma Galvan’s salsa is that we can’t stop eating it. Served warm, the dark cherry-colored salsa tastes fresh and made with love. A sweet little heat just tickles the tongue. Multiple salsas? No. Free: Yes. Chips: Perfection, crisped. Grade: Excellent. Other: This downtown Tex-Mex restaurant, as famous for its lack of menus as its food, was honored as an “American Classic” in 2008 by the James Beard Foundation. less IRMA’S ORIGINAL Address: 22 N. The champion? An unusual minced-red-onion salsa that’s almost a relish, lit up by fruity habanero chile and twinged with fragrant Mexican oregano. A touch of olive oil and orange rounds out the flavors and textures. Brilliant on everything from chips to the mesquite-grilled, Norteño-style beef that’s a specialty here. Multiple salsas? Yes. The tomatillo salsa, the mildest of the four, is a tart, spring-green purée. The perfectly calibrated red salsa, slightly pulpy and flecked with chile seeds, gets an intriguing umami note from chicken broth, and it bursts with front-of-the-mouth heat that spreads and fades to a lingering warmth. Fourth comes a bright, sunny habanero/papaya purée in which the papaya’s fruitiness tempers the distinctive habanero sear while salt sharpens it. Free: Yes. Chips: Sturdy, fried-in-house totopos with a layer-y effect. Grade: Extraordinary (red onion; red salsa); excellent (tomatillo, habanero). Other: Though the salsas merit a trip in themselves, the Norteño-style food at this upscale, dining-clubby Bellaire spot is terrific, and the house margarita, shaken and served straight up, is one of the city’s best. less SALTILLO MEXICAN KITCHEN Address: 5427 Bissonnet; saltillomexicankitchen.com Salsafication: You get four-count-’em-four table salsas to play with, each one formidable in its own right. It hits the front of the palate and the tongue, and flecks of cilantro give it an herbal bite. It’s not complex, but it’s lively. Multiple salsas? Yes. A creamy green salsa that’s very mild, without much going on other than a tiny hint of cilantro and a mere touch of heat on the finish. Free: Yes. Chips: Standard issue. Grade: Good (red). Other: These popular suburban Tex-Mex spots give you a lot of serviceable food for the money, and the happy-hour margarita prices ensure that they’re busy even in mid-afternoon. less GRINGO’S MEXICAN KITCHEN Address: 10 Houston-area locations; gringostexmex.com Salsafication: The red table salsa from this suburban chain is a fairly pureed, cool fresca version that packs some very pleasant ... more Image 43 of 64 EL HIDALGUENSE Address: 6719 Long Point; facebook.com/El-Hidalguense-56805544314 Salsafication: Chiles rayados, the dried and wood-smoked pods of an heirloom jalapeño unique to Mexico’s Hidalgo state, are the key to the deep, dark, thrillingly intense table salsa at this family-run regional spot. The salsa made from these chiles is so dusky it can appear almost black, and the varietal is hotter than your average jalapeño by a good bit. Mutiple salsas? No. Free: Yes. Chips: Do the job. Grade: Extraordinary. Other: The house salsa is a serious enhancement to the Hidalguense specialties of lamb barbacoa cooked in maguey leaves and whole cabrito al pastor. A good tart tomato bite and an edge of cliantro leaves and stems are backed up by a deep dried red-chile burn (we’re guessing guajillos) that spreads slowly and doesn’t quit. The closer to prime tomato season, the better it gets, but it is formidable even in mid-winter. Mutiple salsas? No. Free: Yes. Chips: Medium-thick with a bubbly crunch, with a few red and green ones scattered through the basket for color. Grade: Excellent. Other: This family-owned East End staple makes a mean enchilada verde de pollo, and mariachis make it festive on weekends. less EL JARDIN Address: 7849 Harrisburg; eljardinhouston.com Salsafication: The warm red table salsa here is not fooling around. We give a slight edge to the sprightly red, a puréed blend that doesn’t overwhelm the flavor of its fried-corn vessel. It has an occasional bite of spice, but for the most part you’ll wonder how you polished off the bowl so quickly. Multiple salsas? Yes. The sour-creamy tomatillo/avocado green sauce also is imminently devourable. Free: Yes. Chips: On the thin side but sturdy enough. Salsa grade: Excellent (red); very good (green). </div> <span class="credit"> Photo: Eric Kayne, For The Houston Chronicle </span> </div> <div class="caption staged"> <div class="slide-count"> <div class="nav-stats"> <span class="label">Image </span><span class="item-count-current">64</span><span> of </span><span class="item-count-total">64</span> </div> </div> <span class="credit"></span> </div> </div> <div id="ctpl-mediumrectangle4" class="ctpl-mediumrectangle clearfix"> <div id="GO300" class="galleryAd"></div> </div> </div> <div class="gallery-overlay-outter lights-on hidden"> <div class="gallery-overlay-inner"> <div class="gallery-overlay-title-container"> <div class="homeLink"> <span class="icon"></span> </div> <div class="gallery-overlay-title">The best places to celebrate National Tortilla Chip Day in Houston</div> <div class="slide-count fade"> <div class="nav-stats"><span class="item-count-current">1</span><span> / </span><span class="item-count-total">64</span></div> </div> <div class="thumbs-close-overlay hdn-analytics" data-hdn-analytics="gallery_thumbs_close|article-gallery-10954977|article-gallery-10954977|0"> <div class="thumbs-close-overlay-label"><span class="icon action"></span>Back to Gallery</div> </div> <div class="gallery-close-overlay fade hdn-analytics" data-hdn-analytics="gallery_overlay_close|article-gallery-10954977|article-gallery-10954977|0"> <span class="icon action"></span> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div><div class="fixed-asset perfectPixel"> <div class="hdnce-e hdnce-item-41836"> <div id="hst-mediumrectangle4" class="hst-mediumrectangle"> <div id="TMP300_3" class="ad_deferrable"> </div> </div> </div></div><strong>Click through the slideshow above to see where to celebrate National Tortilla Chip Day in Houston according to Houston Chronicle food experts Alison Cook, Syd Kearney, Greg Morago and Jody Schmal... </strong>
It's National Tortilla Chip Day and we proclaim that there is no better place to celebrate this amazing holiday than in Houston.
According to the official documentation behind the day at the <a href="http://www.nationaldaycalendar.com/national-tortilla-chip-day-february-24/" target="_blank">National Day Calendar website</a> the salty, fried treats were first mass-produced in Los Angeles sometime in the 1940s.
<div class="hdnce-e hdnce-item-47758"> <div class="fixed-asset perfectPixelWide ndn_embed" id="ndn-video-player-1" data-config-distributor-id="90000" data-config-width="100%" data-config-height="9/16w"></div> </div><strong>YIKES: <a href="/food/article/Spicy-tortilla-chip-is-so-spicy-it-s-sold-as-one-9240828.php" target="_blank">Spicy tortilla chip is so spicy it's sold as one, single chip inside a coffin-shaped box</a></strong>
They were born as a way to make use of misfit tortillas that before this were likely thrown away.
They also make a great salsa, queso, and guacamole delivery system, if you're not up for just using a a spoon.
<strong>DIPPING IN: <a href="/entertainment/restaurants-bars/article/The-Salsa-Project-Where-to-get-sauced-in-Houston-7390960.php" target="_blank">Where to get sauced in Houston</a></strong>
These days most of them are made out of corn tortillas, but the best and most decadent ones come from flour tortillas. Pair those with gooey queso and you are on the way to paradise.
There is a reason that chips and salsa was made the official state snack of Texas, the extra thousands of calories be damned.
<strong>MAKE IF OFFICIAL: <a href="/news/houston-texas/texas/article/Texas-taco-expert-makes-the-case-for-tacos-as-the-10921450.php" target="_blank">Texas taco expert makes the case for tacos as the official dish of Texas</a></strong>
Here in Houston you cannot escape tortilla chips and that is what we would like to call a good problem to have.
<div class="asset_media asset-media"> <div data-player-id="1479f628-8230-4c11-b9b8-cd1d71ce804d" class="hearstPlayer" data-player-host="player.hearst.io"></div> <div class="caption"> Pizza? Nachos? At the SAME TIME? Super Bowl Party: Upgraded. Today, we're showing you how to make Pizza Nachos! What You'll Need- CREAM SAUCE: 1-½ Tablespoon Unsalted Butter ½ Tablespoons Olive Oil 2 cloves Garlic, Minced finely 3/4 cups Heavy Cream 1 pinch Salt ¼ cups Parmesan Cheese, Grated - 4 cups Your Favorite Crispy Tortilla Chips 2/3 cups marinara sauce (or pizza sauce) handful of fresh basil, torn handful of parsley, chopped 1 cup Mozzarella Cheese, Shredded 1 cup Cheddar Cheese, Shredded Pepperoni and/or sausage (cooked) Steps: Place tortilla chips in a baking pan Mix and heat cream sauce ingredients, then drizzle onto chips Top with your favorite toppings, cheese, and another layer of chips, then more toppings Bake at 400 degrees for 7 minutes
<span class="credit"> Media: Brandpoint </span> </div> </div>Houston has chips and salsa most everywhere, or at least something akin to it. Papadums and various chutneys really hit the spot at an Indian place.
There is an embarrassment of riches when it comes to Tex-Mex restaurants in Houston so you should have no problem finding somewhere to celebrate National Tortilla Chip Day. Just go back to the place you celebrated National Margarita Day at earlier this week. You left your debit card there anyway.
</div>
